me.wobblyyyy.pathfinder2.scheduler

Class Task

  • java.lang.Object
    • me.wobblyyyy.pathfinder2.scheduler.Task

  • public class Task
extends java.lang.Object
    An instruction or Task that can be used in conjunction with a Scheduler to automate Pathfinder's operation.

    If you have an autonomous routine where carefully-timed execution is important, you can make use of a scheduler to manage that time for you, all from within Pathfinder.

    Since:
    0.0.0
    Author:
    Colin Robertson

    • Constructor Detail

      • Task

        public Task(Trajectory trajectory,
            double minTimeMilliseconds,
            double maxTimeMilliseconds)
        Create a new Task.
        Parameters:
        trajectory - the trajectory the task is responsible for following. this can be a non-functional trajectory if you'd like.
        minTimeMilliseconds - the minimum amount of time (in milliseconds) that the task must take to execute.
        maxTimeMilliseconds - the maximum amount of time (in milliseconds) that the task is allowed to execute.
        See Also:
        newTask(Trajectory, double, double), newUntimedTask(Trajectory), newTaskWithMinimumTime(Trajectory, double), newTaskWithMaximumTime(Trajectory, double), newWaitTask(double)

    • Method Detail

      • newTask

        public static Task newTask(Trajectory trajectory,
                           double minTimeMilliseconds,
                           double maxTimeMilliseconds)
        Create a new Task.
        Parameters:
        trajectory - the trajectory the task is responsible for following. this can be a non-functional trajectory if you'd like.
        minTimeMilliseconds - the minimum amount of time (in milliseconds) that the task must take to execute.
        maxTimeMilliseconds - the maximum amount of time (in milliseconds) that the task is allowed to execute.
        See Also:
        newTask(Trajectory, double, double), newUntimedTask(Trajectory), newTaskWithMinimumTime(Trajectory, double), newTaskWithMaximumTime(Trajectory, double), newWaitTask(double)

      • newUntimedTask

        public static Task newUntimedTask(Trajectory trajectory)
        Create a new task.
        Parameters:
        trajectory - the trajectory the task is responsible for executing.
        Returns:
        a new untimed task.
        See Also:
        newTask(Trajectory, double, double), newUntimedTask(Trajectory), newTaskWithMinimumTime(Trajectory, double), newTaskWithMaximumTime(Trajectory, double), newWaitTask(double)

      • newTaskWithMinimumTime

        public static Task newTaskWithMinimumTime(Trajectory trajectory,
                                          double minTimeMilliseconds)
        Create a new task.
        Parameters:
        trajectory - the trajectory the task is responsible for executing.
        minTimeMilliseconds - the minimum amount of time (in milliseconds) that the task is REQUIRED to take before its execution finishes.
        Returns:
        a new task, with a minimum time.

      • newTaskWithMaximumTime

        public static Task newTaskWithMaximumTime(Trajectory trajectory,
                                          double maxTimeMilliseconds)
        Create a new task.
        Parameters:
        trajectory - the trajectory the task is responsible for executing.
        maxTimeMilliseconds - the maximum amount of time (in milliseconds) that the task is ALLOWED to take before it is forcibly marked as finished.
        Returns:
        a new task, with a maximum time.

      • newWaitTask

        public static Task newWaitTask(double howLongToWaitMilliseconds)
        Create a new task. This task does not move the robot - rather, it waits for a certain amount of time before being marked as done. This can be used like the Thread.sleep(long) method.
        Parameters:
        howLongToWaitMilliseconds - how long the wait task should be.
        Returns:
        a new task with a specified wait length.

        Returns:

      • getStartTimeMilliseconds

        public double getStartTimeMilliseconds()
        Get the task's start time, in milliseconds.
        Returns:
        the task's start time, in milliseconds. If the task has not yet been started, this method will return 0.

      • start

        public void start(double startTimeMilliseconds)
        "Start" the task. This should almost always be handled by a Scheduler, not manually.
        Parameters:
        startTimeMilliseconds - the time the task is starting at.
